STARTING THE FULL EXPANDED MANUAL  ●   PDF #1 — Battery Modeling & Sizing Manual  ●   Part 1 (Expanded)  ●  ●   BATTERY MODELING AND SIZING MANUAL  ●   AI ENERGY MODELING PLATFORM  ●   RAW TEXT, HIGH DETAIL, STRUCTURED FORMAT  ●   VERSION 2.0 (EXPANDED)  ●   SECTION 1 — INTRODUCTION  ●   1.1 Purpose of This Manual  This manual defines the complete set of engineering principles, mathematical models, calculation rules, AI prompting logic, safety constraints, dispatch strategies, and evaluation procedures required to model and size commercial and industrial battery storage systems. It is designed to be ingested by AI systems and used to support calculations for peak demand reduction, energy arbitrage, demand response participation, backup power analysis, incentive qualification, and integrated multi-measure optimization. All content in this document is deterministic, non-hallucinatory, and based on real-world engineering principles, utility program rules, and industry-standard best practices.  ●   1.2 Background and Intent  Battery modeling is traditionally performed by specialized engineers using a wide range of tools including load modeling platforms, financial spreadsheets, utility-specific tariff engines, or simulation tools like NREL SAM. This document translates these engineering requirements into a fully text-based form so that AI tools can replicate this reasoning without ambiguity, inconsistency, or hallucination. The intent is to give an AI system the capability to:  Perform engineering-grade modeling from minimal inputs.  Suggest optimal battery sizes based on user goals such as ROI, DR eligibility, payback, or bill reduction.  Identify utility program incentives automatically.  Calculate savings using deterministic formulas, not estimates or guesses.  Prevent incorrect or physically impossible modeling results.  Explain results to non-engineers in plain language.  Adapt to varying data quality and automatically fill missing details using established inference logic.  ●   1.3 Types of Battery Systems Addressed  This manual applies to:  Lithium iron phosphate (LFP) BESS systems

Nickel manganese cobalt (NMC) systems  AC-coupled BESS  DC-coupled BESS  Modular containerized battery systems  Behind-the-meter commercial batteries  Front-of-the-meter DR-only batteries (with proper modifications)  ●   Not all logic applies to all chemistries, but the overall modeling approach is valid for most commercial systems installed today.  ●   1.4 Inputs Required by the Battery Model  The model can operate with high-quality or low-quality inputs. Ideal inputs include:  Interval data (kW every 15 minutes or 5 minutes)  Monthly billing data (kWh, kW, $)  Utility tariff structure including:  Peak, part-peak, and off-peak energy rates  Non-coincident demand charges  On-peak demand charges  Seasonal variations  Battery specification data from a library including:  Nominal power (kW)  Nominal energy (kWh)  Usable energy fraction  Round-trip efficiency  Allowed C-rates (charge and discharge)  Allowed depth of discharge  Cycle life and warranty constraints  Inverter rating  Site metadata including:  Address  Climate zone  Building type  Square footage  Operating schedule  User-driven goals such as:  Maximize ROI  Minimize payback  Maximize peak shaving  Qualify for a specific DR program  Qualify for SGIP, CEFO, OBF  Find the smallest battery that meets a target demand reduction

●   1.5 Modeling Assumptions  When inputs are missing, the model will rely on inference rules defined in this document.  The model must explicitly state which assumptions were applied.  The model must never fabricate data that violates physical laws.  The model must always disclose uncertainty when assumptions are used.  ●  ●   SECTION 2 — BATTERY FUNDAMENTALS (EXPANDED)  ●   2.1 Power (kW)  Battery power defines the maximum instantaneous rate at which the battery can deliver or absorb energy. It is primarily limited by the inverter but may also be restricted by internal battery chemistry, thermal constraints, and manufacturer-defined discharge limits. Peak shaving depends directly on power rating because demand charges are based on instantaneous or interval demand.  ●   The model must always compare the following:  Battery nominal power  Battery continuous discharge rating  Inverter continuous AC rating  Inverter short-term power rating  Warranty discharge limit  ●   Peak shaving uses the lowest of these values.  ●   2.2 Energy (kWh)  Energy defines how much total energy a battery can store. It determines how long the battery can maintain a specific discharge rate. For example, a 100 kW / 100 kWh battery at 100 kW can discharge for 1 hour. Batteries with high energy relative to power perform better in long-duration events such as extended demand charge windows or DR events requiring more than one hour.  ●   The model must never assume energy equal to nominal energy; it must account for usable capacity and degradation.  ●   2.3 Usable Energy and Depth of Discharge  Actual usable energy depends on:  Depth of discharge limit (e.g., 80–90 percent)  Battery temperature  Age of the battery  Inverter conversion losses  Cell balancing overhead  ●   Usable energy equals:  Nominal energy multiplied by usable fraction.  ●   Different manufacturers define usable fraction differently, such as:  Total battery capacity minus reserved buffer

Full usable window defined in warranty  Charge windows for solar clipping  ●   The model must always track usable energy separately from nominal energy.  ●   2.4 Round Trip Efficiency  Round-trip efficiency is the product of charging efficiency and discharging efficiency. The model must use round-trip efficiency to calculate arbitrage savings and, in some cases, DR energy requirements. Efficiency reduces delivered energy and directly impacts economics.  ●   Typical sources of losses:  Inverter conversion  DC cabling  Internal resistance  Cooling systems  Power control system inefficiencies  ●   The model must not assume constant efficiency. For example, LFP batteries often peak at 94 percent at moderate C-rates but fall to 85 percent during high C-rate discharge or low temperatures.  ●   2.5 Charge Constraints  Charging limits may be lower than discharging limits. Many batteries restrict charging to 0.5C even if discharging can be 1C. AI must check manufacturer charge limits before modeling arbitrage that requires full recharge within off-peak windows.  ●   2.6 Inverter Rating and Derating  Inverter rating is a hard limit on power. The model must always use AC-side inverter power when calculating peak shaving and DR capacity.  ●   Inverters also derate due to:  Temperature  Altitude  Voltage limits  Overload protection  ●   In extreme heat, a 100 kW inverter may be limited to 80 kW.  ●   The model must apply derating rules when environmental data is available.  ●

BATTERY MODELING AND SIZING MANUAL  PART 2 — EXTENDED ENGINEERING CONTENT  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 3 — C-RATE, DISCHARGE DURATION, AND PHYSICS (EXTENDED)  3.1 Formal Definition of C-Rate  C-rate is the ratio of a battery’s discharge power to its energy capacity.  C-rate determines how quickly a battery would fully discharge if it maintained rated power for the entire time.  C-rate = Power_kW / Energy_kWh  If P is discharge power and E is usable energy, the theoretical discharge time (ignoring losses) is:  Duration_hours = E / P  Duration_hours = 1 / C  3.2 Derivation from First Principles  Consider a battery with energy density U (Wh) and a discharge rate I (A).  Power is P = V × I  Energy is E = V × Q  C-rate is defined at the cell level as:  C = I / Q

Mapping cell-level C to system-level C requires pack-level voltage and capacity normalization. For AI purposes, system-level C is sufficient.  3.3 Why C-Rate Determines Applicability  Battery applications have fundamentally different constraints:  Arbitrage: Requires sustained multi-hour discharge  Peak Shaving: Requires fast ramp AND 1–2 hours of output  DR: Requires sustained output with recovery time  UPS: Requires extremely high C-rate for seconds-long output  3.4 AI Rules Governing C-Rate  AI must enforce these rules:  Rule 1: If duration < peak-event duration → penalize or reject battery  Rule 2: If C-rate > OEM warranty max → reject battery  Rule 3: If C-rate < minimum required for use-case → reject battery  Rule 4: If inverter_kW < battery power → use inverter_kW for C-rate  Rule 5: If temperature derating applies → adjust C-rate downward  Rule 6: Always recompute C-rate using usable energy, not nominal energy  3.5 Typical Manufacturer C-Rate Limits  LFP:  Charge: 0.5C  Discharge: 1.0C  NMC:  Charge: 0.3C–0.5C  Discharge: 0.75C–1.25C  3.6 Degradation Impact of C-Rate  Cycle life decreases approximately exponentially with increasing C-rate:  Life_fraction ≈ exp(−k × (C_rate / C_nominal))  Where k ≈ 1.0–1.5 for most chemistries.  3.7 Real-World C-Rate Constraints  Batteries may advertise 1C capability, but real operational limits reduce this:  Thermal derating at high ambient temperature  Voltage sag under high current  Inverter current limits  PCS firmware caps  DoD and SOC window enforcement

AI must factor these.  SECTION 4 — PEAK DEMAND SHAVING ENGINE (EXTENDED)  4.1 Identifying True Peak Demand  Peak demand is the highest measured demand interval in a billing cycle.  PeakDemand = max(interval_kW)  AI must:  Ignore anomalous single-interval spikes  Identify multi-hour plateau peaks  Determine whether the peak is HVAC-driven, process-driven, or random  4.2 Peak Event Segmentation  To model shaving, AI must identify the “peak event window” — the contiguous time span around the max demand during which demand exceeds a threshold (e.g., 90% of the peak).  EventWindow = intervals where kW >= 0.9 × PeakDemand  This gives event duration:  EventDuration = length(EventWindow)  4.3 Peak Shaving Algorithm  Given battery_kW and battery_kWh:  MaxReduction_kW = min(battery_kW, inverter_kW)  MaxPossibleDuration = battery_kWh / MaxReduction_kW  If MaxPossibleDuration >= EventDuration:  EffectiveReduction = MaxReduction_kW  Else  EffectiveReduction = battery_kWh / EventDuration  4.4 Annual Demand Savings Formula  DemandSavings = EffectiveReduction × DemandCharge × 12  DemandCharge may have:  Non-coincident component  On-peak component  Seasonal component

AI must always select the applicable demand charge for the peak period.  4.5 Edge Cases  Case: Peak event lasts 3 hours; duration = 2 hours  → AI must proportionally reduce savings  Case: Battery discharge capped at inverter  → Use inverter_kW  Case: Two peaks of equal size  → Only the highest month matters  → But AI should warn if modeling uncertainty exists  Case: Negative battery savings due to DR reservation  → AI must detect conflicts between DR and peak shaving  4.6 AI Guardrails  Guardrail 1: Never produce “peak”, “part-peak”, and “off-peak” demand savings. Demand is one number.  Guardrail 2: Never assume spike-shaving is sustainable.  Guardrail 3: Always validate shaving duration.  Guardrail 4: Document any assumptions imposed due to missing interval data.  SECTION 5 — ARBITRAGE ENGINE (EXTENDED)  5.1 Time-of-Use Arbitrage Prerequisites  Arbitrage requires price spread > 0:  Spread = PeakRate − OffPeakRate  If Spread <= 0: ArbitrageSavings = 0  AI must not rely on part-peak arbitrage unless user explicitly requests it.  5.2 Charging Constraint  Battery must recharge during off-peak window.  EnergyRequiredForNextDay = RawDailyDischarge  ChargeCapacity = InverterLimit × OffPeakHours  If ChargeCapacity < EnergyRequired:  DailyDischarge = ChargeCapacity × Efficiency

5.3 Daily Discharge Computation  RawDailyDischarge = min(batt_kW × ArbitrageHours, batt_kWh)  DeliveredEnergy = RawDailyDischarge × RoundTripEfficiency  5.4 Annual Arbitrage  AnnualDischarge_kWh = DeliveredEnergy × 365  AnnualArbitrageSavings = AnnualDischarge_kWh × Spread  5.5 Multi-Period Arbitrage  AI should only use:  Off-peak charge  On-peak discharge  Part-peak should only be used if TOU structure requires it.  5.6 AI Guardrails  Guardrail: Never triple-count arbitrage across peak, part-peak, off-peak.  Guardrail: Arbitrage only occurs once per day unless user specifies multi-cycle mode.  Guardrail: AI must check DR conflicts.  STOP HERE  This is ~20% of the full-length manual, and now includes far more depth, math, and reasoning.  Below is   PART 3   of the Battery Modeling & Sizing Manual — now written as if it is an engineering textbook + NREL whitepaper + utility DR implementer handbook + AI rulebook all combined, in   pure raw text ,   no formatting ,   no markdown ,   sectioned for AI ingestion , and   massively expanded .  This section will cover:  • Full DR mathematical modeling  • Complete degradation + lifetime modeling  • More detailed C-rate physics  • Multi-period demand modeling  • Full dispatch logic  • Warranty logic  • DR program rules  • Mathematical derivations  • Optimization and AI rules

Voltage = OpenCircuitVoltage − InternalResistance * Current  Because power equals voltage multiplied by current, high C-rates reduce effective AC output. These constraints must be respected by any engineering model, dispatch strategy, or optimization engine. Technical constraints exist to prevent:  Overloading  Overheating  Overvoltage

Undervoltage  Exceeding warranty limits  Accelerated degradation  Safety hazards  Invalid modeling physics  An AI energy modeling engine must implement all constraints deterministically and must never allow exceptions.  1.2 Constraint Categories  This manual organizes battery constraints into eight primary categories:  1.   Inverter-limited constraints  2.   Cell chemistry constraints  3.   Thermal constraints  4.   Voltage and current constraints  5.   SOC window constraints  6.   Depth of discharge constraints  7.   Manufacturer warranty constraints  8.   Grid-code and safety constraints  1.3 Constraint Enforcement Hierarchy  The AI must enforce constraints in the following order:  Level 1: Safety constraints  Level 2: Manufacturer constraints  Level 3: Thermal constraints  Level 4: Inverter constraints  Level 5: Chemistry constraints  Level 6: Warranty constraints  Level 7: Economic optimization  Nothing overrides safety or manufacturer constraints, regardless of economic benefit.

SECTION 2 — INVERTER-LIMITED CONSTRAINTS (DERIVATION)  2.1 Inverter as the Primary AC-Side Constraint  A battery’s inverter converts DC energy into AC power. The inverter generally becomes the dominant limit on power output, even when the battery pack could theoretically provide more.  Let:  P_batt = DC-side maximum discharge capability  P_inv = AC inverter rating  P_AC = actual delivered AC power  The constraint is:  P_AC = min(P_batt, P_inv)  2.2 Inverter Clipping  Inverter clipping occurs when battery DC-side power exceeds inverter AC-side rating.  If P_batt > P_inv:  ClippingLoss = P_batt − P_inv  EnergyDelivered = P_inv × duration  This means adding more DC battery modules does   not   increase AC power if inverter is undersized.  AI must detect and prevent overvaluation of oversized DC energy.  2.3 Inverter Efficiency  Inverters have conversion efficiency:  η_inv ≈ 0.96−0.99 depending on load.  Actual AC output:  P_AC = P_DC × η_inv  2.4 Partial Load Efficiency Curve  Inverter efficiency drops at low loading. Typical curve:  η_inv(P) = η_max − α(1 − P/P_inv)^2

Where α ~ 0.04 for many systems.  AI must reduce arbitrage savings when battery frequently operates at low AC loading.  2.5 Inverter Overload Capability  Some inverters support short-duration overload (e.g., 110 percent for 10 seconds).  AI must not misuse this for peak shaving or DR modeling.  Overload is for fault ride-through only.  SECTION 3 — CELL CHEMISTRY AND ELECTROCHEMICAL LIMITS  3.1 Nernst Equation and Cell Voltage  Battery cell voltage is governed by:  V = V0 + (RT/nF) ln(activities)  During discharge:  Voltage decreases as concentration gradient forms.  High current accelerates voltage sag.  3.2 Internal Resistance  Each battery cell has internal resistance R_int. During discharge:  V_actual = V_OCV − I × R_int  Power delivered:  P = V_actual × I  As current increases:  Voltage sag increases  Power efficiency decreases  Heat increases as I^2 R losses  3.3 Maximum Discharge Current  Maximum current I_max is defined by chemistry.  C-rate = I / Q  Where Q is capacity in amp-hours.

AI must compute:  I_required = P_required / V_nominal  If I_required > I_max → battery cannot supply required power.  3.4 Charge Rate Limitations  Charge rates are usually half of discharge rates for safety.  Lithium plating risk increases dramatically below 0°C.  AI must apply:  If Temperature < 0°C → ChargeRate_max = 0  If 0 < Temperature < 10°C → ChargeRate_max ≤ 0.25C  If Temperature > 35°C → Reduce ChargeRate_max by 10–30 percent  3.5 Cell Balancing Constraints  Cells in a pack must stay balanced within millivolts.  When near 100 percent SOC, balancing circuits activate and reduce charge acceptance.  AI must derate charging near SOC ceiling.  SECTION 4 — THERMAL CONSTRAINTS (EXTENDED DERIVATION)  4.1 Heat Generation  Heat generated:  Q = I^2 × R_internal × t  Higher C-rate → higher heat → thermal risk.  AI must compute predicted internal temperature rise:  ΔT = Q / (m × Cp)  Where:  m = battery mass  Cp = heat capacity  4.2 Cooling System Limits  Cooling power P_cool sets maximum sustainable C-rate.  If Q_gen > P_cool → derating required.

AI must compute:  MaxC_sustainable = sqrt(P_cool / (R_internal × V_nominal))  4.3 Thermal Runaway Threshold  Thermal runaway occurs when:  dT/dt > heat dissipation rate  AI must not operate near these thresholds.  4.4 Ambient Temperature Constraints  At high ambient temperatures:  SOC window shrinks  Charge rate shrinks  Cycle life worsens  Internal resistance increases  AI must derate based on temperature.  4.5 Thermal Degradation Equation  Calendar degradation increases with temperature as Arrhenius relationship:  k = A exp(−Ea / (RT))  Higher T accelerates degradation.  AI must model life reduction at high average temperatures.  SECTION 5 — VOLTAGE AND CURRENT LIMITS  5.1 Voltage Window  Each chemistry has voltage operating window:  LFP: ~2.5V to 3.65V per cell  NMC: ~3.0V to 4.2V per cell  Do NOT allow discharge past lower voltage.  Do NOT allow charge beyond upper voltage.  AI must enforce voltage cutoffs.  5.2 Current Limits  MaxCurrent = C_rate_max × Q

If required current > MaxCurrent:  Power request must be reduced.  5.3 Voltage Sag Model  At high current:  Voltage drops → reduces power → reduces arbitrage and shaving effectiveness.  AI must compute:  V_loaded = V_OCV − I × R_internal  If V_loaded < inverter_min_voltage → inverter trips.  5.4 Cable and Busbar Constraints  Current flowing through cables generates additional I^2R losses and heating.  AI must enforce limits on wiring.  SECTION 6 — SOC WINDOW CONSTRAINTS (DERIVED)  6.1 SOC Limits Defined by Manufacturer  SOC_min and SOC_max define allowable energy window.  Typical values:  SOC_min = 10 percent  SOC_max = 90 percent  Usable window = 80 percent  AI must enforce:  If SOC <= SOC_min → discharging stops  If SOC >= SOC_max → charging stops  6.2 Dynamic SOC Window Shrinkage  At low temperatures, SOC_min increases.  At high temperatures, SOC_max decreases.  AI must compute adaptive SOC window.  6.3 SOC Calculation  SOC evolves based on:  SOC_next = SOC_curr − (Power * Δt) / UsableEnergy

AI must track SOC continuously.  6.4 SOC Reserve for DR  AI must reserve energy for DR events by ensuring:  SOC >= Reserve_kWh / UsableEnergy  6.5 SOC Hysteresis  SOC boundaries have hysteresis to avoid oscillation.  SECTION 7 — DEPTH OF DISCHARGE AND USABLE ENERGY  7.1 DoD Definition  Depth of Discharge = fraction of usable capacity consumed.  DoD = ΔE / E_usable  7.2 DoD and Lifetime  Cycle life decreases as DoD increases.  Relationship:  Cycles(DoD) = k × DoD^(−α)  Where α ~ 1.2 for LFP and ~1.4 for NMC.  7.3 Partial Cycling  Partial cycles accumulate proportional wear:  CycleEquivalent = sum(DoD_i)  AI must compute cycle-equivalent usage.  7.4 Usable Energy Reduction Over Time  Use:  E_usable(t) = E_initial × (1 − degradation(t))  AI must adjust savings by year. ------------------------------------------------------------  BATTERY TECHNICAL CONSTRAINTS MANUAL  PART 2 — WARRANTY, DEGRADATION, DR, BMS RULES  RAW STRUCTURED TEXT  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 8 — MANUFACTURER WARRANTY CONSTRAINTS (EXTENDED ENGINEERING DETAIL)  8.1 Purpose of Warranty Modeling  Manufacturer warranties strictly govern how batteries may legally and safely operate. Warranty violations result in voided support, accelerated failures, thermal risk, or unusable equipment. AI must enforce these constraints with zero tolerance.  8.2 Warranty Operating Envelope  Every battery has a documented warranty operating envelope. These define:  Maximum discharge C-rate  Maximum charge C-rate  Allowed operating temperature range  Maximum number of cycles per year  Maximum depth of discharge  Maximum average DoD  Maximum ramp rates  Maximum calendar years  Retention requirement (e.g., 70 percent capacity at 10 years)

AI must retrieve or infer these if unknown.  8.3 Warranty Capacity Retention Curve  Manufacturers state that battery capacity will degrade according to:  CapacityRetention(t) = C_initial − (k_cal * t) − (k_cycle * CycleEquivalent(t))  Where:  k_cal = calendar degradation rate  k_cycle = cycle-based degradation rate  CycleEquivalent is sum of DoD-weighted cycles.  8.4 Calendar Degradation Derivation  Calendar degradation follows Arrhenius dependence:  k_cal(T) = A * exp(−Ea / (R_gas * T_abs))  Where:  A = pre-exponential factor  Ea = activation energy  T_abs = absolute temperature  R_gas = gas constant  Higher temperature accelerates degradation.  8.5 Cycle Degradation Derivation  Battery lifetime decreases exponentially with DoD.  Empirical relationship:  Cycles(DoD) ≈ C0 * DoD^(−α)  Where α ~1.2–1.5 for Li-ion cells.  AI must compute equivalent cycles as:  CycleEquivalent = Σ(DoD_i)  8.6 Total Lifetime Prediction  RemainingLifeYears = min(  CalendarLifeLimit,  CycleLifeLimit  )  If remaining life < analysis horizon, AI must include replacement cost.

8.7 Warranty DoD Constraint  If DoD > DoD_warranty_limit, operation is invalid.  AI must cap usable energy at warranty DoD.  8.8 Warranty Temperature Constraint  If T < Tmin or T > Tmax, AI must reject the scenario.  Warm climate or cold storage introduces derating or modification.  8.9 Warranty Charge/Discharge Constraints  If requested C-rate > warranty C-rate:  AI must force derating or reject configuration.  8.10 Warranty Cycle Limit per Year  If cycles/year > maximum allowed:  AI must throttle arbitrage cycles  Reduce DR event participation  Adjust savings downward  8.11 Degradation-Cost Modeling  DegradationCost = ReplacementCost / ExpectedCycleLife  AI must subtract degradation costs from annual savings when needed.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 9 — ADVANCED DEGRADATION MODELING  ------------------------------------------------------------  9.1 Two-Dimensional Degradation Matrix  Degradation is a function of both DoD and temperature.  AI must use 2D lookup model:  Degradation(DoD, Temp) = f1(DoD) + f2(Temp) + interaction_term  Cycles degrade faster at high temperatures and high DoD.

9.2 Rainflow Counting Method  For irregular cycling profiles, the industry uses “rainflow counting” to extract cycle depths.  AI must approximate:  CycleEquivalent = sum(DoD_i extracted by rainflow)  Even if using simplified methods, AI must not double-count cycles.  9.3 Temperature-Dependent Cycle Life  Cycle life scales with temperature using Arrhenius factor:  CycleLife(T) = BaseLife * exp(−k*(T − T_ref))  9.4 SOC-Dependent Degradation  Leaving battery at high SOC increases degradation.  AI must reduce arbitrage cycles if SOC window is frequently full.  9.5 Accelerated Aging Scenarios  AI must detect hazard scenarios:  Repeated deep cycles  High daily cycles  Low-temperature charging  High-temperature operation  High C-rate operation  Long-term storage at high SOC  9.6 End-of-Life Definition  EoL occurs when usable capacity reaches 70–80% of initial.  AI must reduce economic benefits in late-life periods.  9.7 Mid-Life Replacement  If life < analysis horizon:  AI must apply:  ReplacementCost at year ReplacementYear  Discounted properly  Update new battery performance post-replacement  ------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 10 — DEMAND RESPONSE TECHNICAL ENFORCEMENT  ------------------------------------------------------------  10.1 DR Technical Requirements  Every DR program has unique technical constraints. Common parameters:  Power commitment (kW)  Event duration (hours)  Event count per year  Ramp time  Notification time  Refractory period between events  Recharge requirement  AI must enforce ALL constraints.  10.2 DR Event Energy Requirement  Required battery energy for event:  E_req = P_commit * H_event  AI must compare E_req to battery usable energy.  10.3 Recharge Feasibility  Batteries must recharge between events.  RechargeEnergy = E_req  RechargePower = ChargeLimit  AvailableTime = OffPeakHours  Recharge feasibility check:  RechargePower * AvailableTime >= RechargeEnergy  If false → DR participation is infeasible.  10.4 SOC Reservation Strategy  During DR windows, battery must maintain SOC high enough to satisfy event.  If DR event at time t:  SOC_min_required = E_req / E_usable  AI must enforce SOC >= this threshold anytime before t.

10.5 DR + Peak Shaving Conflict  If DR event overlaps with facility peak:  Battery cannot perform both at full power.  AI must choose based on user’s priority goal.  10.6 DR + Arbitrage Conflict  If battery is dispatched for arbitrage overnight and fails to recharge in time:  DR eligibility fails.  AI must warn and modify dispatch algorithm.  10.7 Multi-Day DR Scenarios  If consecutive DR events occur, SOC behavior must be modeled across days.  10.8 Real-Time DR (Fast DR)  Fast DR programs require 1–5 minute ramp times.  Most C&I batteries cannot achieve this without inverter surge.  AI must mark such programs as “Not Eligible” unless battery supports high-speed discharge.  10.9 Frequency Response Constraints  Frequency response requires sub-second ramp:  Ramp < 0.5 seconds  Inverter must be grid-forming or grid-following with fast tracking  AI must treat frequency response as “Not Eligible” for normal BESS.  10.10 DR Dispatch pseudocode  If DR_event == true:  Discharge = min(P_commit, inverter limit, P_available_from_SOC)  SOC decreases accordingly  If SOC < required → DR violation → invalidate scenario  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 11 — BMS FIRMWARE CONSTRAINTS

------------------------------------------------------------  11.1 Purpose of BMS  The BMS enforces safety, longevity, thermal protection, and charge control.  Even if the AI calculates theoretically possible behaviors, the BMS may override them.  11.2 BMS-Imposed Power Caps  BMS may limit power dynamically based on:  Temperature  SOC  Cell imbalance  Cycle count  Fault flags  AI must recheck battery power at each interval.  11.3 Temperature-Based BMS Derating  If T > T_thresh:  Battery power is reduced  If T > T_shutdown:  Battery shuts down  Typical shutdown at 60–70°C cell temp.  11.4 SOC Enforcement  BMS stops charging when SOC >= SOC_max  BMS stops discharging when SOC <= SOC_min  AI must reflect this behavior.  11.5 Fault Mode Behavior  On fault:  BMS opens contactor  Battery stops discharging and charging  AI must set battery power = 0  11.6 Communication Failures  If communication with EMS is lost:  Battery enters safe mode  AI must handle fallback behaviors (e.g., idle state)

11.7 Balancing Behavior  When cells drift, balancing reduces charge rate or usable SOC.  AI must reduce charge acceptance near SOC ceiling.  11.8 Protection Algorithms  Overvoltage  Undervoltage  Overcurrent  Over-temperature  Under-temperature  Isolation fault  BMS shuts off battery.  AI must adopt conservative constraints reflecting BMS intervention.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 12 — INVERTER CONTROL & PCS FIRMWARE  ------------------------------------------------------------  12.1 PCS Control Loops  The power conversion system uses:  Current control loop  Voltage control loop  Phase-locked loop  Grid synchronization  AI must understand that inverter output is controlled, not free-running.  12.2 Inverter Ramp Rate  Inverters typically allow ramp rates:  dP/dt <= MaxRampRate

Example: 10 kW per second  AI must respect ramp rate limits.  12.3 Grid Support Functions  Inverters may be required to:  Provide reactive power support  Ride through voltage dips  Follow volt-var curves  Limit power factor  AI must not violate grid-code constraints.  12.4 Inverter derating at high temperature  PCS temperature limits reduce AC power.  AI must derate output accordingly.  12.5 Voltage and Frequency Ride-Through  AI must enforce:  Under-voltage lockout  Over-voltage lockout  Over-frequency lockout  Under-frequency lockout  In these conditions, battery disconnects.  12.6 PCS Startup and Shutdown Times  PCS often requires 30–180 seconds to start or stop.  AI cannot assume instantaneous availability.  BATTERY TECHNICAL CONSTRAINTS MANUAL  PART 3 — SAFETY, THERMAL RUNAWAY, UL9540A, NFPA 855  RAW STRUCTURED TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 13 — THERMAL RUNAWAY MODELING AND PREVENTION  13.1 Purpose of Thermal Runaway Modeling  Thermal runaway represents the most severe catastrophic failure mode in lithium-ion battery systems. Any engineering, AI, or dispatch model must incorporate thermal constraints to prevent simulation of conditions that could theoretically trigger runaway events.  Thermal runaway cannot be “controlled” once initiated; prevention is the only acceptable strategy. The AI must therefore implement strict boundaries to ensure all modeled operating conditions remain safely within allowable thermal limits.  13.2 Root Causes of Thermal Runaway  Thermal runaway may originate from:  Internal short circuits  Mechanical penetration  Manufacturing defect  Lithium plating followed by dendrite formation  Overtemperature  Overvoltage  Overcurrent  External fire exposure  Poor ventilation causing trapped heat  Failure of cooling systems  Localized thermal gradients  AI must model and avoid all operational conditions that increase thermal runaway probability.  13.3 Exothermic Reaction Model  Thermal runaway begins when the rate of heat generated internally exceeds the rate at which the cooling system can remove heat.  Define:  Q_gen = heat generated internally  Q_dis = heat dissipated (cooling, convection, radiation)  Thermal runaway condition:  Q_gen > Q_dis

Internal heat generation approximated by:  Q_gen = I^2 × R_internal + ExothermicChemicalHeat  At high temperatures, chemical heat generation increases exponentially.  AI must approximate:  If Temperature > Threshold_1 (typically 80°C) → elevated risk  If Temperature > Threshold_2 (typically 120°C) → runaway inevitable  13.4 Thermal Mass and Heat Capacity  Battery pack thermal characteristics defined by:  ΔT = Q_gen / (m × Cp)  Where:  m = mass of battery  Cp = specific heat capacity  AI must model rapid temperature rise at high current or low mass systems.  13.5 Hot Spot Formation  Cells do not heat uniformly. Localized hot spots cause early runaway.  AI modeling must be conservative and assume uniform temperature only for safety modeling.  If inadequate cooling or high C-rate is involved → derate power.  13.6 Cooling System Failure Logic  If cooling fails:  Q_dis = 0  Thus, runaway threshold is reached quicker.  AI must disable high-discharge or high-charge-rate models when cooling assumptions are unknown.  13.7 Early Detection Indicators  AI should model that early warning indicators include:  Cell voltage imbalance  Higher-than-expected internal resistance  Slow charge acceptance  Sudden temperature rise (>3°C per minute)  If any indicator predicted → AI must flag “Unsafe Operating Envelope”.  13.8 AI Guardrails for Thermal Runaway  AI must not:

Model C-rate > manufacturer limit  Allow operation above 55°C sustained temperature  Allow charging below 0°C  Allow discharging beyond thermal envelope  Predict peak output for periods longer than thermal capacity  Ignore cooling limitations  Assume unlimited thermal dissipation  Any breach must produce a critical error.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 14 — UL9540A ENGINEERING ENVELOPE  ------------------------------------------------------------  14.1 Purpose of UL9540A  UL9540A is a destructive fire testing methodology that determines propagation risk in a battery energy storage system (BESS). AI must respect UL9540A findings implicitly because they define minimum fire separation, acceptable cabinet layouts, and containment requirements.  14.2 What UL9540A Tests Determine  Propagation behavior  Flaming and non-flaming failure modes  Gas release characteristics  Thermal runaway cascading potential  Maximum fire spread  Extinguishment feasibility  AI must treat UL9540A as hard safety boundaries.  14.3 Thermal Propagation Limits  AI must understand that UL9540A results determine if:  Modules require physical separation  Systems require firewalls

Sprinklers are required  HVAC requirements apply  14.4 Maximum Allowable Capacity per Unit  Many AHJs (Authorities Having Jurisdiction) impose limits such as:  600 kWh per fire zone  1 MWh per room  Container spacing rules  AI must never propose aggregated systems violating these limits.  14.5 Gas Venting Requirements  UL9540A dictates gas venting strategy.  AI must assume:  Closed-room installations require mechanical ventilation  Outdoor cabinets require exhaust clearance  14.6 Thermal Barriers  UL9540A results may specify minimum spacing between racks.  AI must assume:  Minimum 3 ft aisle spacing unless otherwise stated  Thermal padding for adjacent racks  14.7 AI Safety Rules  Do not propose battery placement without verifying UL9540A spacing.  Do not model cooling loads without confirming UL-based thermal output.  Do not treat battery cabinets as “zero propagation” unless certified.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 15 — NFPA 855 SITINGS, DISTANCE, AND BUILDING RULES  ------------------------------------------------------------  15.1 Purpose of NFPA 855  NFPA 855 governs installation of energy storage systems in buildings. AI modeling must incorporate code-driven constraints for battery placement, ventilation, fire suppression, and monitoring.

15.2 Indoor ESS Installation Limits  AI must assume the following unless overridden by UL9540A-compliant certifications:  Maximum 600 kWh per fire zone  Dedicated ESS room with fire separation  Two-hour rated fire barrier  Fire suppression system (sprinkler or clean agent)  Dedicated ventilation pathway  No ESS in egress paths  15.3 Outdoor ESS Installation Rules  Outdoor units must maintain:  3–10 ft separation between cabinets  10–20 ft distance from building openings  Noncombustible pads  Weatherproof enclosures  15.4 Rooftop Installations  AI must enforce:  Structural engineering review  Wind load compliance  Clearance from mechanical intakes  Smoke venting considerations  15.5 Fire Detection Requirements  NFPA 855 requires:  Thermal detection  Smoke detection  Gas detection  Emergency shutoff  AI must assume these requirements apply to all systems.  15.6 Fire Suppression  ESS must have:  Automatic sprinkler or water-mist system  Thermal suppression agent  Manual override  AI must note that inadequate suppression reduces allowable battery size.  15.7 Monitoring & Emergency Functions  System must integrate with:

Fire alarm system  Remote monitoring  Emergency stop  First responders panel  AI must incorporate these into siting logic.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 16 — SAFETY DISTANCE, FIRE PROTECTION, AND LAYOUT MATH  ------------------------------------------------------------  16.1 Fire Zone Definition  A fire zone is a volume of space where a failing ESS could produce unacceptable thermal propagation.  AI must divide large installations into fire zones.  16.2 Maximum Energy per Fire Zone  Typical cap: 600 kWh  If system > 600 kWh → must be divided into zones.  16.3 Spacing Rule  If battery modules have non-zero propagation rating:  Minimum distance = D_prop  If modules certified as propagation-resistant:  Distance can be reduced.  AI must never assume propagation-resistance unless explicitly specified.  16.4 Heat Flux Modeling  Fire spacing is derived from radiant heat flux:  HeatFlux = k * (Temperature^4) / Distance^2  NFPA requires below threshold at adjacent cabinets.

16.5 Wind and Venting  Outdoor ESS spacing is influenced by ventilation direction. AI must include:  Prevailing wind  Gas dispersion  Access paths for firefighters  16.6 Vertical Clearance  Heat plume rises. AI must enforce:  Minimum vertical clearance above cabinet  Avoidance of overhead hazards  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 17 — GRID-CODE, RIDE-THROUGH, AND ELECTRICAL SAFETY  ------------------------------------------------------------  17.1 Inverter Ride-Through Requirements  Per IEEE 1547, inverters must:  Ride through voltage dips  Ride through frequency excursions  Provide volt-var and freq-watt functions  AI must not simulate behavior violating ride-through capability.  17.2 Anti-Islanding Constraints  Inverters must disconnect during grid outages.  AI cannot model grid export during outage unless part of microgrid with UL-1741 SA certification.  17.3 Voltage Limits  AI must enforce:  V_min  V_max  If battery SOC correlates with voltage, AI must reduce discharge near voltage limits.

17.4 Frequency Limits  AI must apply:  F_min  F_max  Under/over frequency lockout durations  17.5 Ground Fault Protection  If ground fault detected, inverter trips.  AI must set P=0 for fault duration.  17.6 Harmonic Distortion  Inverter must adhere to THD limits.  High discharge power can exceed THD → derating required.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 18 — RECHARGE, RECOVERY, AND CYCLING CONSTRAINTS  ------------------------------------------------------------  18.1 Recharge Time Calculation  RechargeTime = RequiredEnergy / ChargePower  AI must verify recharge fits within off-peak window.  18.2 Recovery Between DR Events  Some DR programs require minimum recovery periods.  Battery must return to baseline SOC before next event.  If:  ChargePower * AvailableTime < RequiredEnergy  Then:  DR eligibility fails.  18.3 Maximum Daily Cycles  For warranty:  Typical limit 1 cycle/day average  AI must penalize arbitrage that requires >1 cycle/day  AI must generate errors above 1.5 cycles/day sustained

18.4 SOC Threshold Before Events  Battery must start arbitrage cycle only if:  SOC_max − SOC_min > EventSOCReserve  AI must enforce SOC guards.  18.5 Multi-Day Behavior  For 2–3 day DR heatwaves:  Battery must maintain consistent SOC reserves  Arbitrage cycles heavily reduced  Peak shaving may be compromised  AI must simulate multi-day intervals if DR included.  BATTERY TECHNICAL CONSTRAINTS MANUAL  PART 3 (CONTINUED)  SYSTEM-LEVEL SAFETY, FAULT BEHAVIOR, GRID COMPLIANCE  RAW STRUCTURED TEXT  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 19 — SYSTEM-LEVEL THERMAL RUNAWAY MODELING  19.1 Multi-Module Propagation  In multi-module ESS configurations, a single cell failure may propagate thermally to adjacent cells or adjacent modules. AI must assume the worst-case unless UL9540A propagation tests state otherwise.

Propagation risk is influenced by:  Cell spacing  Thermal barriers  Cooling system architecture  Module-to-module physical separation  Energy density per rack  Rack ventilation  AI must treat each module as a separate potential ignition source and evaluate the probability of cascading thermal failure.  19.2 Propagation Modeling  Let:  T_local = temperature of failing cell  T_adjacent = temperature of adjacent cell  ThermalCoupling = k * (T_local − T_adjacent)  Propagation is possible if:  T_adjacent exceeds its own runaway threshold after receiving thermal flux.  AI must assume:  High thermal coupling in tightly packed modules  Lower thermal coupling with fire-resistant materials  19.3 Worst-Case Gas Release  Thermal runaway releases:  Vent gases  Flammable electrolytes  Toxic compounds  Opaque smoke  The volume of gas G produced from a single cell failure is given approximately by:  G = m_cell * GasFactor  Where GasFactor typically equals 2–8 times the cell volume.  AI must assume gas release in enclosed spaces and incorporate ventilation as a constraint for indoor installations.  19.4 Pressure and Deflagration  ESS rooms require pressure-relief mechanisms to prevent structural damage. AI must recommend:  Mechanical exhaust fan sizing

Explosion relief vents  Control of ignition sources  19.5 Firefighter Hazard Modeling  ESS must be considered a hazardous environment. AI must account for:  Firefighter access paths  Standby energy remaining in the system  Toxic gas release  Thermal hotspots  Risk of re-ignition  AI must avoid proposing installations without adequate emergency access.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 20 — ELECTRICAL FAULT BEHAVIOR  ------------------------------------------------------------  20.1 DC Fault Behavior  DC faults can include:  Short circuits  Ground faults  Arc faults  Overcurrent  Overvoltage  Connection failures  AI must assume all DC wiring must be modeled under NEC Article 706 and 690.  20.2 Short Circuit Modeling  Short circuit current approximated by:  I_sc = V_nominal / R_total  Where R_total includes internal resistance + line resistance.  AI must treat short-circuit current as extremely high and instantaneously damaging.

20.3 Overcurrent Protection  Battery circuits require:  Fast-acting DC breakers  Fuses  Contactor systems  AI must model these devices as instantaneous event halters that disconnect the battery under fault.  20.4 AC Fault Behavior  On AC side, inverter offers overcurrent protection and anti-islanding.  AI must incorporate inverter AC fault trip logic:  Trip conditions triggered when:  I_AC > I_max  V_AC outside allowable range  Frequency outside allowable range  20.5 Arc Fault Behavior  Arc faults generate high heat and can induce ignition.  AI must ensure that DC cabling meets arc-fault detection requirements and GFDI protection.  20.6 Isolation Fault  If insulation resistance decreases below threshold, BMS trips.  AI must treat isolation fault as:  Battery offline  All power output zero  No DR or arbitrage possible  20.7 AI Guardrails  Under no circumstances may the AI propose:  Higher current than breaker rating  Operating conditions during faults  DR or arbitrage during fault states  Battery operation during anti-islanding lockout

------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 21 — MICROGRID, BACKUP, AND ISLANDING CONSTRAINTS  ------------------------------------------------------------  21.1 Backup Power Envelope  Backup operation differs from arbitrage or DR because battery must operate during an outage in island mode. AI must incorporate:  Minimum backup SOC  Instantaneous switching capability  Load shedding logic  Duration of backup window  BackupSOC_min = RequiredBackupKWh / E_usable  21.2 Microgrid Islanding  If battery participates in microgrid islanding:  Inverter must be grid-forming  PV must be curtailed or controlled  Frequency and voltage regulation must be enforced  AI must never assume grid-forming capability unless explicitly stated.  21.3 Black Start Constraints  Black start capability means the battery can start the microgrid from zero power.  This requires:  Internal UPS mode  Soft start sequences  Regulated voltage output  AI must not assume this capability.  21.4 Load Prioritization  Backup operation requires:  Essential load identification  Load shedding curves  Critical load runtime guarantees  AI must compute runtime only for essential loads.

21.5 Transfer Time Constraints  Critical loads require transfer times < 10 ms.  Typical BESS transfer times = 50–200 ms.  Thus, BESS cannot serve true UPS loads unless paired with UPS hardware.  AI must mark UPS requests as unsupported unless hybrid system specified.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 22 — LONG-TERM DEGRADATION FORECASTING  ------------------------------------------------------------  22.1 Five-Dimensional Degradation Model  Battery degradation depends on five dimensions:  Temperature  C-rate  DoD  SOC window  Cycle count  AI must track all of these simultaneously.  22.2 Degradation Equation  One standard form is:  Degradation_total = f_cal(T) + f_cycle(DoD, C-rate) + f_SOC(SOC_avg)  Where:  f_cal = calendar aging  f_cycle = cycle aging  f_SOC = high SOC stress  22.3 Calendar Aging Model  Calendar aging is temperature-driven:  k_cal = A * exp(−Ea / (R * T))  Total aging = k_cal * years  AI must reduce capacity annually.

22.4 Cycle Aging Model  Cycle aging modeled as:  ΔCapacity_per_cycle = k_cycle * DoD^α  Where α from 1.1 to 1.4.  AI must count cycles using rainflow-equivalent cycles.  22.5 SOC Stress Model  High SOC increases oxidation:  Stress_SOC = k_SOC * (SOC_avg)^β  β typically around 0.5 to 1.0.  AI must penalize long time at > 90 percent SOC.  22.6 Degradation Distribution  AI must predict degradation as:  Capacity_year(t) = Capacity_initial * (1 − degradation_total(t))  Degraded capacity reduces effective arbitrage and peak shaving over time.  22.7 End-of-Life Determination  EOL threshold usually 70–80 percent capacity.  AI must estimate when battery crosses EOL and reduce available kWh accordingly.  22.8 Replacement Logic  If analysis horizon > lifetime:  Battery must be replaced  Replacement cost discounted  New battery resets degradation  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 23 — GRAY-AREA CONSTRAINTS AND SPECIAL CASES  ------------------------------------------------------------  23.1 Cold Weather Operation  Below freezing, lithium-ion cannot accept charge.

AI must enforce:  Charge_power = 0 if T < 0°C  Reduced charge if 0 < T < 10°C  23.2 High Altitude Constraints  Air density decreases → cooling impaired  AI must derate battery power at high altitudes.  23.3 Partial Shaving  If peak is short spike < 15 minutes, battery may still shave it even with low duration. AI must use intelligent spike detection.  23.4 Multi-Interval Demand Charges  Some utilities use:  Fifteen-minute  Hourly  Daily peak windows  AI must adjust logic accordingly.  23.5 Solar-Integrated Constraints  If coupled with PV:  DC-coupled: battery charges from PV before grid  AC-coupled: limited by inverter  Hybrid: special constraints  AI must differentiate.  23.6 ITC (Investment Tax Credit) Eligibility  Charging must be mostly from renewable energy (75–100 percent depending on rules).  AI must enforce charging-source constraints.  23.7 Rapid Cycling  High-frequency cycling for grid services accelerates degradation. AI must disallow unless battery designed for high cycle count.  BATTERY TECHNICAL CONSTRAINTS MANUAL

PART 4 — AI GUARDRAILS, LOGIC, VALIDATION, MASTER EQUATIONS  RAW STRUCTURED TEXT  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 24 — AI SAFETY AND GUARDRAILS (ENGINEERING RULES)  24.1 Purpose of AI Guardrails  AI must never propose, estimate, calculate, or recommend any operation that is physically impossible, violates safety rules, violates warranty limits, or produces double-counted or fabricated savings. Guardrails ensure AI behaves as a deterministic engineering system, not a creative generative model.  24.2 Primary Guardrail Domains  Battery physics  Thermal safety  Electrical constraints  Inverter behavior  Warranty and degradation  Utility tariff integrity  DR event compliance  Charging limitations  SOC constraints  DoD constraints  Cycle count limits  Grid-code compliance  24.3 Absolute Hard Stops  Under NO circumstances may AI:  Model discharge at power > inverter rating  Model discharge at power > manufacturer C-rate  Model energy use beyond usable kWh  Model charging below 0°C  Model discharging below minimum temperature  Model arbitrage where peak rate ≤ off-peak rate

Model DR event longer than battery duration  Double-count demand savings  Model demand savings in multiple TOU buckets  Operate battery outside SOC window  Ignore thermal derating  Ignore manufacturer warranty constraints  Assume zero degradation  Assume infinite cycles  Assume zero thermal resistance  Assume unlimited recharge capability  24.4 Warning-Level Guardrails  If data is missing, AI must report uncertainty.  If peak appears as single needle spike, AI must detect and apply smoothing.  If SOC insufficient for next event, AI must reduce arbitrage forecast.  If multiple DR events scheduled, AI must check recharge feasibility.  If user goal conflicts with constraints, AI must request clarification.  24.5 Goal Prioritization Guardrail  If battery cannot meet all priority tasks, AI must apply:  Priority = user-selected goal  THEN apply:  Peak shaving > arbitrage  DR > arbitrage  DR vs peak = depends on user goal  AI must expose trade-offs clearly.  24.6 No Hallucination Policy  AI must never:  Invent battery specs  Invent incentives  Invent tariff structures  Invent demand events  Invent manufacturer warranties  Invent system capabilities  AI may only:  Calculate  Simulate  Predict

Infer from established rules  Request missing data  24.7 Conservatism Requirement  If uncertainty exists or data is missing:  AI must choose the conservative (safe, physically possible) interpretation.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 25 — AI TRAINING LOGIC FOR BATTERY MODELING  ------------------------------------------------------------  25.1 Purpose  This section defines how the AI should "think" about batteries at an expert-engineer level. It includes the complete mental model for:  Recognizing what data is required  Identifying missing details  Determining feasibility  Selecting measures  Running dispatch internally  Running constraint checks  Producing structured reasoning  25.2 The AI Battery Reasoning Loop  At every modeling request, AI must:  Step 1: Identify user goal  Step 2: Identify available data  Step 3: Fill missing data with industry-safe assumptions  Step 4: Build physical constraints envelope  Step 5: Run peak shaving model  Step 6: Run arbitrage model  Step 7: Run DR model  Step 8: Apply inverter, thermal, warranty constraints  Step 9: Compute financial metrics

Step 10: Evaluate feasibility  Step 11: Compare multiple battery options  Step 12: Rank by user goal  Step 13: Generate explanation and caveats  25.3 How AI Should Handle Ambiguous Requests  If user says, “I want a battery sized correctly”, AI must ask:  What is the primary goal?  Demand reduction?  Arbitrage?  DR participation?  Incentive qualification?  Backup?  Mixed?  AI must not guess goal.  25.4 Training Set of Internal Heuristics  AI must internalize the following industry heuristics:  Heuristic 1: Commercial peaks last 45–120 minutes.  Heuristic 2: Most arbitrage occurs once per day.  Heuristic 3: Efficiency < 90% for discharge > 1C.  Heuristic 4: DR rarely pays more than $50–150 per kW-year.  Heuristic 5: If DoD > 80% daily, degradation becomes severe.  Heuristic 6: Battery lifetime = min(calendar, cycle).  Heuristic 7: Oversized batteries rarely increase ROI.  Heuristic 8: Undersized batteries miss value streams.  Heuristic 9: Tariff details strongly affect economics.  Heuristic 10: Incentive availability can reverse recommendations.  25.5 When AI Should Say “I Need More Data”  If peak duration unknown  If tariff unknown  If DR event duration unknown  If inverter rating unspecified  If ambient temperature data missing  If SOC window ambiguous  If manufacturer constraints unknown

------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 26 — VALIDATION MATRIX (ENGINEERING TEST CASES)  ------------------------------------------------------------  26.1 Purpose  This matrix ensures the AI battery model never produces invalid or physically impossible predictions. Each test must pass before battery results are used.  26.2 Validation Categories  Peak shaving correctness  Arbitrage correctness  DR correctness  C-rate correctness  Thermal correctness  Warranty correctness  Financial correctness  Cycle correctness  26.3 Validation Test Cases (Full)  Test 1 — Basic Peak Shaving  Battery: 100 kW / 100 kWh  Peak: 350 kW  Event: 45 minutes  Expected shave: 100 kW sustained  If AI outputs >100 kW → fail  Test 2 — Duration-Limited Shaving  Battery: 100 kW / 50 kWh  Event: 2 hours  Duration limits shave: 50kWh / 2hr = 25 kW  If AI outputs >25 kW → fail  Test 3 — Arbitrage Spread Zero  Peak-offpeak spread = 0  Arbitrage = zero  If AI outputs >0 arbitrage savings → fail

Test 4 — Impossible DR Event  Battery: 100 kW / 100 kWh  DR event: 100 kW for 2 hours  Energy required = 200 kWh  Battery only has 100 kWh  Scenario must be rejected  Test 5 — Inverter-Limited  Battery: 200 kW pack  Inverter: 100 kW  Peak shaving must be limited to 100 kW  Test 6 — Low Temperature Charging  Temperature = −5°C  Battery cannot charge  If arbitrage charging simulated → fail  Test 7 — Over-Cycling  Arbitrage cycles > 2/day  DR cycles > warranty  AI must flag warranty violation  Test 8 — Double Counting Demand  AI cannot give savings in peak + part-peak + off-peak  Demand savings must only exist once  Test 9 — Negative SOC  Model must never produce SOC < 0 or > 100  Test 10 — Tariff Migration  If battery changes tariff, AI must recalc base bill.  26.4 Validation Outcomes  If a test fails:  AI must not produce results  AI must issue a diagnostic message explaining failure  AI must request additional input or suggest revised assumptions  ------------------------------------------------------------
