Since Q_{avail} = f(T), the thermal solver must strictly run   before   the capacity logic in each step.  ●   Metering Mode:   In BTM applications, the batt_meter_position variable is critical. If set to "Buy All / Sell All," the battery is effectively behind a separate meter, and self-consumption logic will fail. It must be set to "Net Metering" for standard BTM peak shaving behavior.  7. Energy Efficiency and Load Management Logic  While SAM is primarily a generation/storage tool, its capabilities extend to   Demand Side Management (DSM) , utilizing logic derived from NREL's   dsgrid   toolkit.  7.1 Load Forecasting Algorithms  For dispatch algorithms like Peak Shaving to function, the system must predict the load. When "Perfect Look-Ahead" is disabled, SAM employs internal forecasting logic.  ●   Simple Moving Average:   The default internal forecaster uses the load from the previous N days to predict the next 24 hours.  ●   Application:   This logic is critical for "learning" controllers in EMS apps. It allows the controller to adapt to changing building usage patterns (e.g., seasonal shifts) without needing complex external weather data integrations.  7.2 Efficiency via Peak Reduction  SAM models energy efficiency not just as "using less energy" (kWh), but as "using energy better" (lower kW peaks). The efficiency logic is intrinsic to the   Grid Power Sorting   algorithm described in Section 4.1. By flattening the load curve, the   effective   efficiency of the grid connection improves (higher load factor). The model allows users to quantify this efficiency gain in financial terms ($ saved / kWh throughput).  Conclusion  The NREL System Advisor Model's battery module represents a convergence of electrochemical physics, thermal thermodynamics, and economic optimization. It distinguishes itself from simple spreadsheet models through its coupled physics engine: efficiency is a function of current (I^2R), capacity is a function of temperature (f(T)), and lifetime is a function of usage complexity (Rainflow).  For application logic libraries, the critical takeaways for replication are:  1.   Adopt Rainflow Counting:   Simple cycle counting is mathematically insufficient for real-world battery usage prediction.  2.   Implement Implicit Thermal Solvers:   Thermal feedback loops are essential for safety and accuracy; explicit solvers risk instability.

3.   Utilize Sorted Grid Power Logic:   The 24-hour look-ahead sorted list is the most effective heuristic for robust demand charge reduction.  4.   Differentiate Constraints:   Logic must rigorously enforce the hierarchy where physical constraints (Voltage/Thermal) always override economic dispatch targets.  By adhering to these algorithmic structures, developers can ensure their applications deliver results consistent with DOE-validated standards and robust enough for commercial deployment. ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 1 — PURPOSE OF THE FINANCIAL MODEL  1.1 Purpose  This manual defines the financial equations, lifecycle cost models, incentive logic, rate-structure modeling, degradation-adjusted economics, loan structures, and AI behavioral rules required to evaluate the economic performance of a commercial battery energy storage system (BESS).  The purpose is to give AI a deterministic, engineering-accurate financial framework that:  Calculates savings correctly  Determines cashflow impacts  Evaluates incentives  Runs NPV, IRR, and payback properly  Prevents inflated or impossible financial outcomes  Explains results clearly  1.2 Audience  This manual is designed for use inside an AI-enabled energy modeling tool supporting:  Sales teams  Engineers  DR aggregators  ESCO modelers  Finance partners  1.3 Modeling Requirements  The financial engine must:  Use deterministic formulas  Respect technical limits from PDF #1 and #2  Enforce tariff rules  Enforce incentive rules  Avoid double-counting  Adjust cashflows for degradation  Handle loan structures correctly  Apply discount rates consistently  Report uncertainty transparently  SECTION 2 — COMPONENTS OF ANNUAL SAVINGS  2.1 Annual Savings  Annual savings come from five major categories:

Demand charge savings  Arbitrage savings  Demand response revenue  Tariff migration value  Operational improvements (HVAC interactions optional)  Annual savings must be reduced by:  Degradation losses  O&M expenses  Cycle penalties (if used)  Loan repayment (in financed scenarios)  2.2 Demand Charge Savings  Demand charges are based on the   highest peak demand   in the billing cycle, not multiple periods.  DemandSavings =  PeakReduction × DemandCharge × 12  Where PeakReduction is determined from the peak-shaving model.  AI must never allow demand savings from multiple TOU categories.  2.3 Arbitrage Savings  Arbitrage revenue:  ArbitrageSavings =  Delivered_kWh_per_day × 365 × (PeakRate − OffPeakRate)  Constraints:  Spread must be positive  Battery must recharge  Cycles per day must be below warranty limits  AI must not assume arbitrage in multiple periods.  2.4 Demand Response Revenue  DRRevenue =  CommittedKW × EventHours × NumEvents × ProgramRate  If DR includes capacity payments:  CapacityPayment =  CommittedKW × MonthlyRate × 12  AI must model DR conflicts with arbitrage and shaving.

2.5 Tariff Migration Savings  Tariff migration occurs when battery enables a more favorable tariff.  MigrationSavings =  AnnualBill_Base − AnnualBill_WithBattery  AI must recompute both full bills.  SECTION 3 — COST STRUCTURE: CAPEX, OPEX, FINANCING  3.1 Total CAPEX Components  AI must sum:  Battery modules  Inverter / PCS hardware  Switchgear  Electrical infrastructure  Controls  Software  Construction labor  Permitting  Engineering  Commissioning  Sales tax  CAPEX must never include incentives.  3.2 Operating Expenses  Annual operating costs include:  EMS software license  Ongoing monitoring  Preventative maintenance  Insurance  Lifecycle replacement accrual  Performance testing  Battery augmentation (if needed)  Typical O&M: 1–3% of CAPEX annually.  3.3 Cycle Degradation Cost  Batteries lose capacity through cycling.  A cycle cost can be included:

CycleCost =  ReplacementCost / (ExpectedCycleLife)  AnnualCycleCost =  CycleCost × CyclesPerYear  AI must include cycle penalties if cycles > 365/year.  3.4 Replacement Cost  If analysis horizon exceeds battery life (e.g., 10-year analysis, 7-year life), AI must apply replacement cost:  ReplacementCost occurs in Year_LifeEnd  DiscountedReplacement =  ReplacementCost / (1 + r)^(LifeEnd)  Replacement cost must appear as a negative cashflow.  3.5 Salvage Value  If battery retains value at the end of analysis:  SalvageValue =  RemainingCapacityValue / (1 + r)^N  AI must not inflate salvage value.  SECTION 4 — PAYBACK METRICS  4.1 Simple Payback  simple_payback =  NetCAPEX / NetAnnualSavings  Where NetCAPEX = CAPEX − incentives.  AI must:  Reject payback if NetAnnualSavings ≤ 0  Warn if payback > analysis horizon  Reject payback if NetCAPEX ≤ 0 without modeling incentives properly  4.2 Discounted Payback  discounted_payback = smallest t where  Σ(NetAnnualSavings / (1+r)^t) ≥ NetCAPEX  4.3 Loan-Adjusted Payback  When financed:

LoanPayback =  TotalLoanPayments / NetAnnualSavings  Loan payments must replace CAPEX in numerator.  AI must not combine both methods.  SECTION 5 — NET PRESENT VALUE (NPV)  5.1 NPV Definition  NPV =  −NetCAPEX + Σ(NetAnnualSavings_t / (1 + r)^t)  Where:  t = year  r = discount rate //must never be negative  5.2 Discount Rate Selection  Typical values:  Commercial: 6–10%  Industrial: 8–15%  Risk-heavy DR: 12–20%  If discount rate missing: AI must request clarification.  5.3 Degradation-Adjusted Savings  NetAnnualSavings must decline as battery degrades:  NetAnnualSavings_t =  DemandSavings_t + ArbitrageSavings_t + DRRevenue_t − OandM_t − DegradationCost_t  Degradation impacts:  usable_kWh  usable_kW  efficiency  cycle performance  5.4 NPV Red Flags AI Must Catch  NPV > 3 × CAPEX → suspected modeling error  NPV negative but IRR high → error  NPV positive but payback > analysis horizon → mismatched assumptions  SECTION 6 — INTERNAL RATE OF RETURN (IRR)

6.1 IRR Formula  Solve r such that:  0 = −NetCAPEX + Σ(NetAnnualSavings_t / (1+r)^t)  AI must solve with numerical iteration.  6.2 IRR Validity  IRR must lie between −100% and +100%.  If outside → invalid.  6.3 Cases IRR Fails  Negative savings first years  Multiple sign changes  Non-monotonic cashflows  AI must respond:  “IRR undefined due to cashflow characteristics.”  SECTION 7 — FINANCING STRUCTURES: CEFO, OBF, LOANS  7.1 CEFO Logic  CEFO mirrors OBF:  No upfront cost  Payments through utility bill  Term cannot exceed bill savings window  Must be cashflow positive  Savings must exceed loan payments  7.2 CEFO Eligibility  AI must check:  SimplePayback <= program limit  LoanTerm <= max term  Customer type qualifies  Technology qualifies  Project under max cost cap  7.3 OBF Logic  OBF uses similar logic but is more rigid.  AI must check payback-based loan term.  7.4 Loan Payment Calculation  Payment =  LoanAmount × (r_month / (1 − (1 + r_month)^(-TermMonths)))

Monthly interest = annual interest ÷ 12.  7.5 Loan Cashflow Analysis  Loan reduces upfront CAPEX but adds annual payment.  LoanCashflow_t =  NetAnnualSavings_t − LoanPayment  SECTION 8 — SGIP INCENTIVE MODELING (EXTENSIVE)  8.1 SGIP Incentive Types  Base incentive  Equity incentive  Equity resiliency incentive  Step-down blocks  Performance-based coupons (cycling)  8.2 SGIP Base Formula  SGIP =  battery_kWh × incentive_rate  Where incentive_rate changes by step.  Typical General Market Step 1 example:  0.50 $/Wh  Step 2: 0.45  Step 3: 0.40  … etc.  8.3 SGIP Equity and Resiliency  Equity incentives may be:  0.85 $/Wh  Resiliency incentives may be:  1.00 $/Wh+  AI must ensure correct categorization.  8.4 SGIP Performance-Based Incentives  Performance factor PF:  PF = measured discharge energy / expected discharge energy  AnnualPerformancePayment =  PF × cycle_energy × performance_rate

AI must model cycle-based performance payments.  8.5 SGIP vs ITC Basis Interaction  SGIP may reduce basis for federal ITC if treated as cost-sharing grant.  If applicable:  ITC_basis = CAPEX − SGIP  ITC = ITC_basis × ITC_rate  AI must evaluate eligibility.  ------------------------------------------------------------  BATTERY FINANCIAL MODELING MANUAL  PART 2 — ITC, BILL RECONSTRUCTION, REPLACEMENT, RISK MODELING  RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 9 — FEDERAL INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT (ITC) MODELING  9.1 Purpose of ITC Modeling  The Investment Tax Credit is one of the most influential financial incentives for battery storage. ITC eligibility rules are strict and depend heavily on charging-source requirements. AI must enforce all IRS rules and avoid any incorrect tax assumptions.  9.2 ITC Eligibility  AI must check the following conditions:  If battery charges more than 75 percent from renewable generation (typically solar) → ITC eligible

If battery is grid-charged more than 25 percent → ITC reduced or disallowed  If battery is standalone without renewable pairing → not ITC eligible under standard rules (unless falling under new IRA provisions)  If battery participates in arbitrage using grid power → ITC may be impacted  AI must never assume ITC eligibility based solely on presence of battery.  9.3 ITC Basis  ITC_basis =  TotalCAPEX − disallowed_incentives − grants − rebates  SGIP may reduce basis depending on classification.  Utility incentives sometimes reduce basis.  AI must:  Remove any grant-type incentive from basis  Keep performance-based incentives untouched (they do not affect basis)  9.4 ITC Calculation  ITC_amount =  ITC_basis × ITC_rate  Where ITC_rate may be:  30 percent (base)  +10 percent (domestic content)  +10 percent (energy community)  Up to 50 percent with stackable adders  9.5 Depreciation Interaction  ITC reduces MACRS depreciation by half the ITC rate.  DepreciableBasis =  ITC_basis × (1 − ITC_rate/2)  AI must enforce depreciation rules if modeling tax effects.  9.6 ITC Clawback Risk  If battery charging % violates rules after commissioning, ITC may be clawed back.  AI must warn in scenarios where arbitrage lowers renewable charging fraction below thresholds.  ------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 10 — UTILITY BILL RECONSTRUCTION AND TARIFF MIGRATION  ------------------------------------------------------------  10.1 Why Full Bill Reconstruction Is Required  Battery modeling fundamentally changes:  Peak demand  Energy usage distribution  TOU timing  Rate eligibility  Minimum charges  Thus AI must reconstruct the baseline and post-battery bills for accurate savings.  10.2 Baseline Bill Reconstruction  BaselineBill =  Σ(EnergyCharges)  ●   Σ(DemandCharges)  ●   FixedCharges  ●   Riders  ●   Taxes  AI must compute:  BaselineEnergyCharges =  Σ(kWh(t) × Rate(t))  BaselineDemandCharges =  PeakDemand × DemandCharge  Where PeakDemand = max interval load in the month.  10.3 Post-Battery Bill Reconstruction  PostBatteryEnergyCharges =  Σ(kWh_after_battery(t) × Rate(t))  PostBatteryDemandCharges =  (NewPeakDemand × DemandCharge)

MigrationBenefit =  BaselineAnnualBill − PostBatteryAnnualBill  10.4 TOU Changes  Some tariffs allow battery customers to switch to a more favorable TOU schedule.  AI must evaluate eligibility by analyzing:  Load factor  Demand thresholds  Renewable pairing  Battery size  Customer class  10.5 Rate Switching Guardrails  AI must never:  Assume incorrect rates  Switch tariffs without eligibility  Ignore seasonal differences  Mix rates from different tariffs  Assume fixed charges identical across tariffs  10.6 Minimum Charges  Many tariffs include minimum charges per month (e.g., $/kW peak load shape or fixed $/month). AI must include these.  10.7 Energy vs Demand Structures  AI must differentiate:  Energy-only tariffs  Demand-only tariffs  Blended tariffs  Tiered tariffs  Critical peak pricing (CPP)  Ratchet tariffs  10.8 CPP Considerations  If tariff includes CPP surcharges:  Battery may reduce CPP impacts by shaving critical peaks.  AI must model CPP savings separately.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 11 — BATTERY REPLACEMENT AND AUGMENTATION MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------  11.1 Replacement vs Augmentation  Replacement: exchange full battery system at end of life  Augmentation: add modules to restore capacity  AI must know difference.  11.2 Replacement Trigger  Replacement required when usable capacity < threshold (typically 70–80 percent).  AI must predict replacement year:  ReplacementYear =  year t where Capacity(t) <= EOL_threshold  11.3 Replacement Cost Modeling  ReplacementCost may equal:  Full CAPEX × replacement_fraction  Where replacement_fraction often 0.4–0.7 of CAPEX due to reuse of PCS, switchgear, and installation infrastructure.  Discounted replacement cost:  ReplacementCost / (1+r)^(ReplacementYear)  11.4 Augmentation Modeling  Augmentation adds capacity over time to maintain SOC margin for DR or shaving.  AI must compute augmentation scenario when:  Degradation makes duration insufficient  DR commitment cannot be met  Peak shaving reduction becomes insufficient  11.5 Augmentation Costs  AugmentationCost_kWh typically lower than initial CAPEX due to reuse of PCS.  AI must express augmentation as mid-horizon capital cost.  11.6 Replacement and Augmentation Interactions  AI must not mix replacement and augmentation incorrectly.  If both required, augmentation occurs first, replacement later.  11.7 End-of-Life Salvage Value  If analysis horizon ends before EOL, salvage value applies.

SalvageValue =  RemainingCapacity × per_kWh_residual_value  Discount to present:  SalvageValue / (1+r)^N  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 12 — DEGRADATION-ADJUSTED FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE  ------------------------------------------------------------  12.1 Why Degradation Matters  Degradation reduces:  Power capability  Energy capability  Efficiency  Cycle life  Dispatch flexibility  DR eligibility  Annual savings must be adjusted downward.  12.2 Adjusted Demand Savings  Shave_t =  min(battery_kW_t, peak_excess)  battery_kW_t decreases over time due to:  Inverter aging  Thermal constraints  Voltage sag  Manufacturer limits on aged systems  DemandSavings_t =  Shave_t × DemandCharge × 12  12.3 Adjusted Arbitrage Savings  ArbitrageSavings_t =  DeliveredDaily_kWh_t × 365 × Spread

Where DeliveredDaily_kWh_t decreases over time.  12.4 Adjusted DR Revenue  If battery capacity decreases:  CommittedKW may be reduced  DR eligibility may be lost  Event durations may exceed battery capability  AI must lower DR revenue in later years.  12.5 Adjusted O&M  O&M may increase with age due to:  Cooling load increase  Maintenance  Balancing issues  Component replacements  12.6 Complete Degradation Model  AnnualSavings_t =  DemandSavings_t  ●   ArbitrageSavings_t  ●   DRRevenue_t  − OandM_t  − DegradationPenalty_t  AI must apply this series annually into NPV calculation.  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 13 — SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS AND RISK MODELING  ------------------------------------------------------------  13.1 Purpose  Battery economics are sensitive to multiple variables. AI must run sensitivity checks to determine project robustness.

13.2 Sensitivity Variables  Demand charge  Spread  Cycle life  Ambient temperature  Tariff changes  Load shape variation  Degradation rate  Incentive availability  Financing rates  13.3 Sensitivity Methods  One-at-a-time (OAT) method: vary one input ±10–20 percent.  Monte Carlo (conceptual only for AI guidance):  vary multiple parameters across ranges.  AI must at least implement OAT.  13.4 Risk Indicators  RiskScore increases if:  NPV extremely sensitive to spread  DR revenue volatile  Degradation rapid  Replacement cost soon  Tariff likely to change  Payback near program limits  AI must warn user if project economically fragile.  13.5 Confidence Rating  AI may assign confidence boundaries to savings based on:  Data quality  Load shape consistency  Battery sizing match  Multiple conflicting incentives  Assumptions required  ------------------------------------------------------------  SECTION 14 — EXTENDED AI GUARDRAILS FOR FINANCIAL MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------  14.1 No Inflation of Benefits  AI must never:  Double-count demand savings  Double-count arbitrage  Count arbitrage in part-peak and off-peak  Add DR on top of arbitrage for same interval  Ignore SOC reserves  14.2 No Invalid Incentive Modeling  AI must not:  Apply SGIP to ineligible systems  Apply ITC to grid-charging batteries  Stack incentives incorrectly  Claim rebates not real  14.3 No Invalid Loan Modeling  AI must not:  Use loan term longer than program allows  Ignore CEFO cashflow positivity rules  Mix simple payback with loan payback  Confuse CAPEX and financed costs  14.4 No Incorrect Discounting  AI must:  Apply discount rate uniformly  Discount replacement costs  Discount performance incentives  Apply correct annual periods  14.5 No Violation of Degradation Effects  AI must not:  Use year-1 savings for all years  Ignore end-of-life  Ignore mid-life replacement  14.6 Transparency Requirements  AI must output:  All assumptions  All formulas  All constraints  All reductions applied  Any warnings
